section.text: Hi. Good morning. Thank you for taking my question. So, I understand that it's too early for 2023 outlook at this point, but if you could please perhaps give us some parameters to frame 2023, like what would you need to see engines in capital markets to get restarted? Is there a way to frame capital market activity in terms of first half versus second half, like when do you think the outlook really starts to get better?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chandni Luthra", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "f899f857-d2d9-40f0-9c66-10c3d639b9c9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Chandni, it's something that we're very focused on and we're working through our budgets right now to really determine what we're expecting in 2023, but from a macro level, you look back to what we said 90 days ago, we view that we would be in a mild recession and that it would raise with peak in Q1 of 2023 and they would start to alleviate through 2023. Our position now as the things have materially changed, we've seen that impacting our capital markets business directly. We are getting hit harder and faster than we were expecting 90 days ago and we're expecting the recession to impact our business for longer than we did 90 days ago. And so looking into next year, we do expect the capital markets to come back likely in the second half of the year, but that return is going to be more muted than what we initially expected when we talk to you in Q2.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Emma Giamartino", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "76858f2b-3373-43ce-a147-b9c7c9be6624", "speaker_title": "Global Group President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Investment Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: That's actually helpful color. Thank you about that -- thank you for that. Switching gears to margins a little bit, so 13% margins in the quarter, down 450 bps, it's better than 3Q '19, but then of course the worst is still ahead of us. So, help us frame margins in the context of 2019 given that the macro is about to get much tougher and what you framed in your answer just recently, how should we think about margins in the context of 2019? Is there a scenario, do you think we go all the way or do you think there is some recourse in the cost cutting plans that you laid out?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chandni Luthra", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "8c1376c9-5b95-46e2-bcb4-36e1b43a3b0d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Yeah, and Chandni I'm going to talk about Advisory specifically because that's the most relevant piece moving, but what you're speaking to. And hopefully it's clear what happened in Q3, but I just want to go through that. In Q3 and we have this on Slide 7 as you as you all saw, I think it's always important to look at our advisory margin excluding OMSRs, that was 30 basis points of the decline, that OMSRs are peer margins, but when they grow, they're adding margin and when they decline 100% of that margin comes out. The second is, we are in because of the phenomenal first half of the year we had and the exceptional growth we delivered, our producers entered higher tranches much earlier than they ever have before. So that was 80 basis points of the margin decline. And those tranches reset at the end of the year. So, we don't expect that to be a headwind in 2023.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Emma Giamartino", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "1e67e0fa-4727-4553-b4fa-09f10d5398e7", "speaker_title": "Global Group President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Investment Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: And then the two remaining pieces are producer recruiting where we are investing in our future growth. In the first half, we delivered again exceptional growth and we were investing in our cost to support that growth going forward. And then on the operating expense side, again, we also were investing in new hires. We are under invested in 2021 simply because revenue accelerated faster than we can pick up our investments and then we also increased -- we have wage inflation just as every other company had.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Emma Giamartino", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "1e67e0fa-4727-4553-b4fa-09f10d5398e7", "speaker_title": "Global Group President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Investment Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: So going forward, what we're seeing looking into Q4, we should expect that operating expense growth to continue to come down. You look at the first half of the year, our operating expense in Advisory was up about -- over 19%. In Q3, our operating expenses came down to 10% growth year-over-year and in Q4 our operating expense should decline year-over-year and this is within Advisory. And that's -- there's two components to how those costs are coming out. One is our discretionary cost levers that we can pull going back on travel and entertainment, continuing to pull back on new hires. Pulling back on new hires takes longer for that to come into our cost savings and then our discretionary bonuses.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Emma Giamartino", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "1e67e0fa-4727-4553-b4fa-09f10d5398e7", "speaker_title": "Global Group President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Investment Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: You will also see some impact from our $400 million cost savings program, but that is going to be a meaningful lag there. Most of those savings you'll see in 2023 and that's because we take action on reducing headcount and there is a lag in terms of when those costs come out of the system. So net where we expect to end the year in Advisory, we expect our margins to be over 19% with an Advisory. Excluding OMSRs, our margins to be over 18% and that's an important number because that is a record margin excluding 2021 when our margins were inflated because our costs had not caught up to our revenue growth.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Emma Giamartino", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "1e67e0fa-4727-4553-b4fa-09f10d5398e7", "speaker_title": "Global Group President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Investment Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Thank you for that detail.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chandni Luthra", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "c89641c7-ccb9-4b59-9241-48c69a147e3a", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Thank you and good morning. And Emma maybe just sticking on this margin discussion in Advisory. So, if I'm understanding this right, if on that Page 7 that 190 basis point drag in the third quarter from opex that actually flips and becomes a little bit of a benefit in 4Q. And so, if I'm kind of understanding in putting some narrative around this, is it just that come 4Q you lose some of the drags on the cost side and the margin side, but you're more impacted by maybe the drawdown on the revenue side?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Anthony Paolone", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "ae0e3839-f17c-4306-88ab-d324286d2b5b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JP Morgan"}

section.text: Yeah. So, in Q4, across Advisory, we're expecting net revenue year-over-year to decline roughly 20% and so -- but we're also expecting margin expansion because of the cost, so you're right.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Emma Giamartino", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "34462ba7-99a5-46d9-9347-cb2679510753", "speaker_title": "Global Group President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Investment Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Okay got it. And then just within Advisory in the quarter, just trying to understand mortgage originations and loan servicing a bit better, just I would have thought mortgage originations would be a little bit more insulated because people kind of have to refinance and do things whereas investment sales, they maybe don't have to sell the asset, but that didn't seem to be the case. Like any thoughts on just maybe why that was or if that like reverts?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Anthony Paolone", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "5a708ab4-fb9e-4961-896f-62a2a0a35756", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JP Morgan"}

section.text: Yeah. Tony, that is just a function of the fact that we had two things go on, rates went up and spreads went up. Typically when you see rates go up the way they did, spreads will come down a little bit. Both of them went up and and people just avoided refinancing because it was so expensive it's that simple. And we had that circumstance play out in a way that was beyond what we would have expected.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "ba350bf0-3015-4940-889b-826f8e18e1af", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Now, here's what I'll say about that. It's going to -- we think in the fourth quarter that you will see financing perform better than new sales. People are just not going to come back and trade assets until interest rates go down and until they think they can get the pricing they want, which will happen after -- in our view, after the Fed starts to go the other direction with interest rates, which as Emma said in her prepared remarks, we think may happen later next year, but that's really what you saw happen in Q3 and especially what you saw happen in September.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "ba350bf0-3015-4940-889b-826f8e18e1af", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Okay. Got it. And then just last one from me on the leasing side. You pointed out offices having been pretty strong, it's also fairly cyclical property type. Like how much more runway do you think is left there to get back to normal when you kind of net that against maybe perhaps activity slowing because of the more macroeconomic factors?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Anthony Paolone", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "95b71972-37a2-4746-b17b-f5ea167fb374", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JP Morgan"}

section.text: Tony when you say how much runway is there till that gets back to normal, give a little more on that. I want to make sure I understand what you're asking here?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "1aa022c3-a399-4ce8-ab3f-2a7b650dfd7f", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Yeah, sure. I was under the impression like office maybe looked particularly good because you were still having some of the post COVID recovery in just decision making, but maybe that's off.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Anthony Paolone", "section_number": 13, "uuid": "9ebbfb4f-dc15-41ec-8fbe-aac394b32449", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JP Morgan"}

section.text: No, no, what's going on is in fact that there was and we talked about this last quarter, there were abundance of renewals in the marketplace to be done. We'll see that continue this year and into next year, but what we also expect to see now is some downward pressure as we go into a recession. There's always downward pressure on leasing in a recession because people are looking around, trying to find ways to defer cost, save money. And so what they -- you have this dynamic that goes on where they extend for a short period of time, etc. So, we expect to see some of that come in and leasing to be more flattish in the fourth quarter, but we still expect some of the benefit from the built up number of renewals that need to be dealt with to occur in the fourth quarter and into next year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "0f863d5e-a0d4-4a3a-97b0-5b3de3d796c0", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Okay. So, it sounds like maybe it's a net kind of flattish number between sort of the renewals getting cleared and the headwind from the macro.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Anthony Paolone", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "5ad99283-beb7-4f87-b756-dc3520ca766e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JP Morgan"}

section.text: That's what we think. And maybe a little down, but that's how we think it's going to play out.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "7e612623-4620-4f90-8de5-e514c7e6551d", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Yeah and Tony for Q4 specifically, we're expecting leasing to be flat.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Emma Giamartino", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "8ed69e9a-c590-4aaf-9bd4-b180f70543c3", "speaker_title": "Global Group President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Investment Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Okay, great. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Anthony Paolone", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "66391e5a-97a4-4165-9f44-2a42bfd2c3bd", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JP Morgan"}

section.text: Great, thanks. Just a couple. Emma just on that last point, you said Q4 leasing to be flat in office. Is that -- I just want to be clear is that year-over-year or sequential?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Sakwa", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "74bdeada-2089-48c9-a41a-cafc39e88fd0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: We cleared that's flat globally across all product types and that's year-over-year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Emma Giamartino", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "9c673382-f7f6-457b-871a-6313b3dc7c7b", "speaker_title": "Global Group President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Investment Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Okay. Thanks. I was wondering if you could just provide any comments on the industrial sales market. I know that's an area that you guys have been fairly active in. It's obviously been one of the more favored asset types within REIT land, but we have seen a pullback in that leasing market as well. So, I'm just curious if you have any comments on kind of industrial cap rates and the appetite today.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Sakwa", "section_number": 22, "uuid": "cc77d2a9-dd19-4679-aaed-27439d7a2624", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Industrial cap rate cycle, all cap rates have gone up. Industrial fundamentals have remained very strong. They've backed off a little bit. We've seen a little bit of downward pressure on rental rates in some areas. We've seen slightly more vacancy, although the fundamentals are very, very strong, the markets held up very well in the major markets, very little vacancy. Strong demand still. So that has created a circumstance where there are buyers for the assets and there are owners of assets and developers -- investors and developers that want to sell, but they're just not going to sell in the current environment because cap rates have ticked up and finance is expensive. And in our own portfolio, as a developer, we've made the choice to defer sales for some of our industrial assets.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "06f5e087-ace6-4ff0-8d25-9533fa730878", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: And I think what happened is we've already comment -- or what will happen as we've already commented, when that circumstance eases and we think that likely will be the second half of next year, those assets in the pipeline will get sold. Pipelines are very strong. The pipelines of assets, sellers want to sell and buyers want to buy are strong and we think starting the second half of next year, you will see all of that free up to a degree and start to -- that market activity start to happen again.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "06f5e087-ace6-4ff0-8d25-9533fa730878", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Great. Just I guess one more question if you could provide any comments around sort of the industrious and office kind of leasing business that you guys have. And I'm just curious what uptake you've seen in that business and just kind of the short-term office leasing business?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Sakwa", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "c0eb8ed7-2cab-4b26-bd08-69cac9c6ad12", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Well, office leasing and industrious, they share some dynamics, but they are different. Industrious provides a capability in the marketplace that's unique, you can get in and out quickly, you can get in and out without capital expenditure, you can adjust the amount of space you have very quickly, you can go into places that you don't intend to be long-term. And with all the uncertainty around the use of office space and where it's going to go, industrious business has done quite well and we believe it will continue to do quite well and we're very excited about that investment and the performance of that investment.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "be7bf3de-770d-4eae-bdd5-cf9c8014abfc", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: We've already commented today on office space. There's what you're seeing in leasing on office space is a pent-up amount of renewal activity and uncertainty about what's going to happen long-term with offices. There's also a big bifurcation in how different parts of the office market are performing with the best buildings, the premier buildings doing quite well with rents up and less quality, less favorite buildings suffering much more.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "be7bf3de-770d-4eae-bdd5-cf9c8014abfc", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Yes, sorry, Bob. My question was unclear. I wasn't trying to follow-up on Tony's question. I was really asking specifically about the trends in industrious and just what maybe market share you are seeing the WeWork's [Indecipherable] the industrious is taking in the Industrial -- sorry in the office leasing business against kind of traditional office leasing?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Sakwa", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "76caa772-b62b-4c7e-ae51-0a245dae33b9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Yeah. And that was my comment. That's where I started with industrious. The trends that industrious is seeing in the marketplace are very positive. We would characterize it as a record level of interest in that type of space and it's been subjected to some different dynamics than regular office space. It creates flexibility, it creates the opportunity to get in and out of office space without capital expenditure, it creates the opportunity to get into a smaller amount of space in more convenient locations that you may not want to commit to long-term and as a result it's doing extremely well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "4ef983b1-f025-4b50-9927-aa998a0d8a48", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Great thanks. That's it from me.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Sakwa", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "7d444bb5-8d41-45e6-b41b-0cd17f6e72ba", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Thank you very much. What are you seeing in the GSE multifamily lending business? Historically, they've been countercyclical providers of capital. They don't price to a securitization exit, at least private label and so their spreads may not be as wide. And they do have ample capacity the FHFA governed lending caps. Are you seeing them step-up in this point of time?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jade Rahmani", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "4a7bc591-f47d-4a43-9cdb-cb11af79a309", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: Jade we are seeing the GSEs pickup in this past quarter. They have contributed a larger portion of our volume than they did in the prior quarter. They picked up from 20% of our volume to 25% in this quarter. So, they are offsetting some of the declines from private lenders, but the entire market is down. And so even though they are picking up, it's not as material as you might expect.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Emma Giamartino", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "fdf15220-907b-48f2-8f07-f7c1106fcc45", "speaker_title": "Global Group President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Investment Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Thank you. In terms of REIs prospects, how sensitive is the outlook to where interest rates are? Meaning if projects once stabilized need to finance at a mortgage [Indecipherable]. Is that going to inhibit sales out of that segment for potentially a longer than expected period?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jade Rahmani", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "e3db18bf-0578-4e92-ac26-543fa92a5d4e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: And jade, are you asking through the remainder of this year?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Emma Giamartino", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "c7ee9e03-d8a5-4a49-89ed-6e94f70e1c1f", "speaker_title": "Global Group President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Investment Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Say for next year. I mean the timing of the outlook isn't that important, but I'm more concerned about if mortgage rates were stickier at say something in the 6% range, would that really inhibit a lot of those projects that are waiting to be sold or would that inhibit the ability to sell those?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jade Rahmani", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "3f6b648c-0589-4d33-8422-5698002c39bf", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: Yeah. So, the way we think about development and we provided a range of conversion and that we take our in process portfolio, which is currently over $19 billion and typically that converts to SLP in the range of 1% to 2% in any given 12-month period. Going into recession and this is what we said last quarter, going into 2023, we'd expect that in a mild recession, we should get to the bottom end of that range, into the 1% range and that's driven by two pieces, one, cap rate expansion, so that we're monetizing the assets at a lower return, but also the ability for us to choose to wait to sell the assets until the environment improves. We have a really strong balance sheet and we have really flexible financing, so that allows us to make the decision that we don't want to monetize in a challenging environment and we don't want to wait to sell. And so, it will be at the low end of the 1%. And then if the environment is very challenging, it could dip slightly below that 1%, but [Technical Issues] that doesn't mean those asset sales and monetizations are going away. Those then appear in 2024 or whenever the market recovers.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Emma Giamartino", "section_number": 35, "uuid": "8badf99e-d299-4313-96d2-92fd6382da04", "speaker_title": "Global Group President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Investment Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: [Speech Overlap] Go ahead. Sorry.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jade Rahmani", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "4570586a-f231-49b2-b65e-1d6a91be2f7a", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: Yeah. I'm going to add to that. That's true of our portfolio and that's true of everybody else's portfolio in general. Those asset sales will happen eventually. The assets are there, they're ready to be moved from one party to another, but the parties aren't going to do that until they feel like they're confident in the fairness of the pricing on the sales side and the buy side and the availability of financing that works.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "66a6c285-4806-422f-98ea-40d423ab2373", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Thank you. Just more broadly speaking on investment management. I mean as long as I've covered this space, the theory has been institutionalization, increased allocations to real estate from LPs, sovereign wealth funds. etc. And for the first time, we're starting to hear chatter that's in the opposite direction that there is an over allocation because of decline in equity markets and fixed income and that LPs are getting nervous about allocating to CRE. Has anything really changed on that long-term secular trend in your view?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jade Rahmani", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "8766eeb2-3d57-41ab-be5d-c10fbb20c2e5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: Not on the long-term sense, nothing at all has changed in that regard. In the short-term, you're describing the denominator effect, which we haven't seen it for a long-time, but we have seen it before. And I think we will revert back to the trends we saw previously over the last decade. We're quite confident that will be the case. That's what we're very actively engaged with capital sources around the world and that's where they're headed at, but we do have their short-term circumstance that's precipitated by the debt markets and also the denominator effect and that's really what we're seeing here -- I'm hearing about.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "29e4bd69-dd3f-4de6-9bc8-b41a518c7462", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Thank you very much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jade Rahmani", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "8731c344-7be4-45c6-be31-34daffb0c508", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: Hi, good morning. I first wanted to dig in more on the GWS new business pipeline. I think that increased significantly in the third quarter. Is there anything specific, I guess, driving that? And is macro uncertainty having any impact there in terms of delaying decision making or could it actually be creating more urgency to outsource to vendors like CBRE in this type of environment? But just like to have some more detail on what you're seeing there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Sheldon", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "4d4a3009-6e62-47d5-a871-49e5330fd207", "speaker_title": "Analyst at William Blair"}

section.text: Stephen, there's a number of factors at play there. Whenever we go into periods of financial stress, companies everywhere look for opportunities to save cost. Our outsourcing offering helps them save costs. It's demonstrably able to do that and so that's helping that capability sell in the marketplace right now. The other thing in times of economic uncertainty is sometimes decision making is slower. And so while we have this large pipeline, you may see some slower decision making. The third thing that's going on is we are continually adding to our capability in that area, our procurement capability is getting better, the data that we can provide clients to help them make decisions is getting much better.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "ff208dd0-49fa-4331-ae32-a6cc855f66ca", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: We have a product called Vantage Analytics that they like a lot that helps them make decisions that causes them to be attracted to us. Our ability to connect our offering around the world and serve them in a way that's consistent is getting better. So, that is all playing to our favor and that's some of what you've seen come through this year in the buildup of the pipeline and the landing of new business. But the cost factor is always at the top of the list when you dig into that business and figure out what clients really want.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "ff208dd0-49fa-4331-ae32-a6cc855f66ca", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Got it. That's really helpful. And then the follow-up. I guess just wanted to ask as we kind of think about FX headwinds. I think you report your currency exposures in the SEC filings for revenue, but just curious if you're expenses would also -- your expense exposure would also closely correlate to that or would call out anything there where there's a material mismatch?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Sheldon", "section_number": 44, "uuid": "816edf64-68a1-429b-a281-6312e81014d6", "speaker_title": "Analyst at William Blair"}

section.text: It generally aligns. Our cost is being impacted in a very similar way to our revenue.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Emma Giamartino", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "e21adb79-8e1f-4907-8d43-66cdd9ed2839", "speaker_title": "Global Group President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Investment Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Okay, great, thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Sheldon", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "1209a463-0537-48fe-b862-fa338bc5267e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at William Blair"}

section.text: Hey good morning. After the global financial crisis, it took, I think probably seven or eight years for industry sales activity to rebound to peak levels. And then after the pandemic, it obviously just took one year. Given kind of what you're seeing in the macro right now, how are you thinking about the pace of recovery of the sales outlook and whether we're seeing deals just delayed or whether deals get canceled?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Patrick O'Shaughnessy", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "80b63617-874e-4c3b-a433-403ae66fb7bf", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Well. Patrick, one thing that's interesting is how long it's been now since the financial crisis. The cycles that we had previous to that were shorter and so that kind of impacts people's thinking. The other thing that impacts people thinking is they forget how deep the financial crisis was and how unusual it was compared to other downturns. But I can tell you what we're seeing now and we've used this term multiple times on this call, pipelines, there is a definitive identifiable pipeline of projects across property types that want to be sold by the owners. And there is a lot of capital out there that wants to buy and neither of them think this is the right time to transact. That's what you're really seeing. We believe that when interest rates start to go the other direction, when the Fed reverse course because they think that the economy has gotten to a point where continued upward pressure on interest rates goes from being at the problem solving circumstance to a problem creating circumstance that we will see that pipeline start to transact and it will recover. We can't give an exact number of years, but it will recover considerably more rapidly than it did coming out of the financial crisis.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "53760397-b84f-40a8-a5b0-6c8720c637fc", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Great. That's helpful. Thank you. And then as to your expense reductions, obviously you guys took some expense actions during the pandemic. How much more room do you have to cut before you get into the muscle and maybe you start potentially losing market share?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Patrick O'Shaughnessy", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "a5113ba5-4ea7-47dd-89be-02994e27a098", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Yeah. Well, Emma commented on the $400 million number that's the number we believe we can cut without impacting our ability to grow the business and serve our clients in the future. A lot of work went in to from the grassroots level up and from top down to identify that $400 million number. And I want to stress again something Emma said, we have a massive amount of our cost basis that flexes automatically when revenues go down, commissions, profit sharing and development and investment management, incentive equity, bonuses all of that is completely independent of this $400 million, $300 million of which we think will be permanent and a $100 million of which we think will come back when things get better and we don't think that, that $400 million will create problems for our business at all.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "6206a067-d531-4cc7-a7ed-797cd752b598", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: Great. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Patrick O'Shaughnessy", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "38e43e7d-aa2b-4462-bec7-f7e0039a9076", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Thank you very much. A question investors often ask is where are commercial or let's just say capital markets overall versus some prior period say 2018, 2017, but I know that you all are constantly hiring producers. So, could you give any sense for what the growth rate in number of producer head count has been on the brokerage side relative to some past period, so that we could adjust for that? And also I think even if commercial real estate prices decline, the absolute nominal dollar of commercial real estate value is probably significantly higher than it was in 2017, so hard to compare next year versus 2017, but any color on that would probably be helpful. Thank you very much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jade Rahmani", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "8db040aa-c050-4248-8ad1-3ac58e7240bd", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: Yeah, Jade, we'll give a conceptual answer to that. We don't have specific numbers on brokers, but we have had a strong year for brokerage recruiting and it was intentional because we believe that the opportunity to grow that business in the long-term is there and we believe it is the right time to get into the market and bring some new brokers on. So, relative to history -- it would stack up well relative to our good brokerage recruiting years in the past, but we don't have specific numbers for you on that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "fb308533-78ec-430a-a983-abc8782e27b1", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

section.text: No. Thank you very much for taking the questions.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jade Rahmani", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "72a84975-43a3-43ce-89e3-685ae471b467", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: Thanks everyone for being with us and we look forward to talking to you again when we report our year end results.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert E. Sulentic", "section_number": 59, "uuid": "fa99148e-639b-424f-b8a3-2c20b5a76ce2", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at CBRE Group"}

title: Q&A for CBRE (CBRE Group) on 10/27/22 8:30 AM ET
